segments.text: Now by 1937, do you pretty well have your career staked out as it was going to exist until 1940?
Were you moving into new fields or pretty well remaining on the California coast?
Well, we were gradually sort of expanding our
our area of interest, we'd started working really off the coast of Southern California.
And in 1940, we did make a cruise as far north as roughly the Columbia River.

And another venture that was in 1939 was a cruise to the Gulf of California, which we made in the winter of that year, which was the first time that any vessel from Scripps had really ventured very far away from home.
And this was really sort of exploring in those days because so little was known.
And I don't know what might have happened if the war had not intervened.
And I think that we would have had to find some larger vessel, and that we would have, presumably within a few years at least, have moved out to operations on sort of an ocean-wide scale.
But actually, I left Scripps in July of 1941, having spent a month prior to that at Woods Hole to learn something about the interpretation
of bathy thermograph observations in terms of underwater sound problems.
And on July the 1st, I moved down to the Navy laboratory on Point Loma, which not as an employee of the Navy, but under one of these war research programs
was funded later on by the NDRC, the National Defense Research Committee, I think it was called.
And this was a essentially federally funded war research program administered through the University of California.
And I stated in this program
at Point Loma until early in 1946.
By that time, the work had been taken over by the Navy itself, but I still continued, as did many of the others there, to be actually as employed by the University of California.
And during the
first year or so down there, the work was primarily, that I was engaged in, was primarily how you might interpret various physical

conditions in the ocean, primarily temperature and salinity and so on, in terms of the acoustic conditions in the ocean, what we used to call the echo-ranging problem, and this gradually gave way to some other environmentally related problems.
But I became more and more involved in general sort of administration
of some of the basic research going on at the laboratory on Point Loma.
And toward the end, I actually was an assistant director in charge of the research, which involved primarily a set of acoustics of various kinds, but a good many other types of activities.
I have several questions on that.
Now, you go to Woods Hole, though, to work with the BT for anti-submarine warfare, don't you?

I did go back and work with Robert Montgomery for about a month, because at that time, as I indicated earlier, we really didn't know what the bathy thermograph was measuring and so on, and also how you might be able to use this kind of information in these underwater sound problems.
And we were all very naive as to what we were doing.
But I contributed my small part here to the whole program in that I was the one who suggested they make photographic copies.
And Montgomery and I worked out the first sort of system
coding these things and keeping the appropriate records and so on, which has persisted for a good many years after that.
Right.
You're looking for ways of measuring thermal claims.
In effect, yes.
There had been some work done by

Columbus Island at Woods Hole by Morris Ewing and some of the other people that were associated with them in the preceding few years, which showed the probable relationship of temperature and humidity conditions on Underwater Sound.

Morris Ewing's contribution, I think, was particularly to show that you could use some of the refraction computations that he was familiar with from his work in geophysics would be applied to these conditions in the ocean.
And of course, it was not directly temperature and salinity that was involved here, but rather the distribution of sound velocity.
And so there were
We had the clue as to what we should be doing, although a lot of the sort of techniques had not been worked out.

particularly during the first year or so, much effort went into devising ways of calculating these so-called ray diagrams and seeing how you could, in a sense, simplify some of the conditions as you observed in the ocean to compute these sort of ray diagrams and so on.
Then a lot of effort was spent in the first year or two of making up what were called sound ranging charts or sonar charts, which didn't depend just on the BT.
We used every scrap of information we could to essentially try and come up with some semi
quantitative approach of the regional differences in sound ranging conditions that might be predicted from known characteristics of the ocean waters.
Why photography?
I'm sorry?
Why photography?
What made you think of photography?

Oh, I guess because my father was a photographer and it seemed to me that the BT slide was like a negative, why not put it in a projector and just make a print from this, which could then be enlarged too, because the original BT slide you really had to insert in a
magnifier in order to read it, we more or less standardized on what was roughly a postcard size reproduction.
All you have to do is stick them in a regular photographic enlarging machine and use fairly contrasty paper.
When you're working, I need to know something else here, too, right now.
Why didn't you go with Revell to the Navy and to Washington at this time?
Why did you choose Point Loma?
Well, here again, there's some kind of interesting things that, if I remember correctly, about 1939, there was some
concern about the international situation and so on.
Revelle had applied for and obtained a reserve commission as an ensign and I applied too.
I think it was somewhat later than that because
Yes, must have been.
I have somewhere in my files a letter that I received from the Navy saying that they regretted they couldn't offer me a commission because they had no foreseeable need for oceanographers.
Of course, Revelle went down to Point Loma at that same time, and I just, I can't really remember how long he was there, but he was there for about a year or two before he went back to Washington.
But I had tried that route, but it didn't work.
And I think that answers it, sure.
And then during those war years, then you're involved in research at Point Loma itself.

Yes, I would, as I look back on it now, I did a good deal of research, particularly in the first year or two, but really what I became more and more involved in was what I would consider a science administration.
things moved very rapidly in those days and so there was a great deal of sort of planning and and a good deal of traveling involved in that that under the NDRC where there were several centers were

work of this kind was going on, and they served as a sort of coordinating function, and so we met at what seemed like fairly frequent intervals for discussions of what we were doing, what we were finding, what we ought to do, and also in trying to prepare sort of manuals and documents of various kinds for the Navy.
So this is part of what I sort of consider as the administrative side.
We weren't involved, I wasn't involved too much with actual sort of budgeting or matters of that kind, but it didn't,

What it didn't involve was us breaking out from the rather narrow kind of confines of individual research and getting involved with the programs and activities of a variety, a relatively large number of people in fields that I had absolutely no familiarity with at all.
And this, I think, was one of the effects of the war,
that those of us who were involved in activities of this kind really got broken away from what would have been a normal sort of pattern of career evolution here.
and got thrust into very large, very complex kind of problems involving fields which were originally at least unfamiliar to us.
That anticipates, as a matter of fact, my next question.
With whom did you come into contact in about 1941 to 1943 that sort of moves you into administrative oceanography here all at once?
Well, Professor Sverdrup was originally

to essentially head up the the kind of oceanographic component at the Point Loma laboratory, but he encountered security problems because of having his family, not his immediate family, but relatives in Norway and so on, and it was felt that he was in a sensitive set of positions, so

they would not give him security clearance and I essentially had to take over what he had might have done and he returned and he never really left it because this was only a part-time sort of activity down Point Loma but he returned so full-time to
to Scripps, and he and Walter Monk, whom we had originally had down at Point Loma with us, and who could not get security clearance.
Sverdrup and Monk took on this study of the wave problem, and I think it started originally under the Air Force's support.

And out of that there's this whole amazingly rapid development of understanding of the problems of wave characteristics, wind wave characteristics, and methods of predicting wind wave conditions and swell and surf and so on.
And then out of that activity came the

training program which was set up at Scripps, which I had no direct contact at all, although I was living within a few miles of it, which brought in a number of young officers from the Air Force and the Navy who were trained in these wave forecasting techniques.
And as we were saying this morning, later on, a number of these young
men returned to Scripps and finished off their doctoral work.

But that was really one of the, I think, very dramatic set of developments during the war, because prior to the time that Sverdrup and Munk turned their attention to this problem, which they had not really
dealt with previously, there was virtually nothing known about the characteristics of ocean waves.
It was a body of theory, but very little connection between the sort of theory and the real conditions.
And there was only a very, very limited literature about wave conditions and wave behavior.
Did you consciously make an effort at about 45 to go to Washington or to DC, or did that just happen?

Well, here again I think Ravel enters the story because he had moved from the Navy laboratory at Point Loma to the Bureau of Ships and in particular to the, I think it was called the sonar design section or something to that name under a

I can't remember his rank now, but Bennett, and had the imagination to see the role and importance of ocean information to the Navy, and yet there was no mechanism by which the Navy could essentially continue the oceanographic studies and so on and other.

there are a number of sort of related threads to the story which are involved in this thing, and that is that, as I mentioned earlier, at Woods Hole and at Point Loma, we prepared, for example, these sonar charts and so on,
they were actually published through the Hydrographic Office.
And so that during the war, they had set up in the Hydrographic Office an oceanographic unit, I believe it was called at that time.
And this was under the direction of Mary Sears, who was being commissioned as a wave.
And they served during the war.

as essentially a publications outlet for some of the material being prepared under these war research laboratory programs, and they did some compilation of various kinds of information, but this was a temporary sort of situation.
And one of the things that Revell and others were able to accomplish was to have the Navy Department set up on a continuing basis an oceanographic section in what was then the Hydrographic Office.
And I was

essentially offered the position, and it looked extremely interesting and important to me at that time to go back and start what was known when I arrived as the Division of Oceanography in the Hydrographic Office.
Of course, the whole thing later became the Oceanographic Office, but it was a division.
Shortly after I arrived, in April of 1946, the oceanographic unit that had been in existence was being phased out, and the new division reached a low ebb of
one girl who helped me and myself.
I left about five years later with over 200 people in the division and operating two sort of what were at that time very large oceanographic vessels for the Hydrographic Office.
So this was, yes, a challenging sort of thing.
I felt that there were urgent needs to keep a sort of a national program going rather than letting things die, as they might have at the end of the war.
And I think this was
Turned out to be quite correct.
What sort of people did you look for when you went to establish this office?
Did you already have some people in mind whom you wished to bring to Washington?
Well, only a few people that I'd known for one reason or another and seemed desirable and seemed appropriate for the job.
people that really were brought in as to be my principal assistants were Clifford Barnes, who you'll probably talk to next week,
But he only spent a relatively short time with us and then returned to the University of Washington.
John Lyman, who you may have encountered, who had been in the Navy all during the war as a reserve officer and had been at Scripps before that.
Thomas Austin, who's now head of the National Data Center, and
young man who'd been at the WAVE program at Scripps during the war, Charles Bates, who's now chief scientist for the Coast Guard.
So those were the, in a sense, senior people who came in early in the game, but what was, it's,
I think interesting looking back that far, which is just over 30 years ago, that at that time there was no classification in the civil service for anybody called an oceanographer.
So one of my first sort of jobs back there was to set up the job descriptions for oceanographers, get them approved by the
the Civil Service Commission and then began to try and recruit some people.
And I very soon found that there weren't very many people to be recruited.
And as any administrator, I abhor as a job vacancy why we were in the position of having to hire people with degrees in physics or chemistry or geology and so on.
with essentially no experience whatsoever in oceanographic problems.
And I soon realized, as I'd learned during the war, that there was a real need for some kind of program to train people or educate people in the field.
And so, as I sometimes remark, I decided to get out of the hiring business and get into the manufacturing business.
opportunity to come to the University of Washington looked attractive to me.
Not only was it sort of intellectually attractive, but I thought there was a very real sort of need here.
Now, there was some graduate programs available in the early years following the war, but
One of the things that really stimulated me into coming to the University of Washington was the opportunity to set up an undergraduate program in oceanography, which had never been attempted before.
I want to return to your trip to Washington, because that's extremely important to us.
I have several questions, though, right here concerning your activities in DC itself rather than Washington state.
Was there much conflict between these civilian oceanographers and Navy personnel when you began to establish this office?
Well, I wouldn't say there was any conflict.
We were looked on as a set of screwballs by the establishment within the Hydrographic Office.
They didn't know quite
thought we were or who we were or anything else.
And so we were allowed really a considerable amount of sort of freedom simply because they had no prior experience in this area.
And this

period, and I can't identify it specifically by year, but the military budgets were being cut back very severely in the late 40s, and along with them the Hydrographic Office was being cut back by major amounts, and yet
the oceanographic program continued to grow, and this of course was looked on with some sort of favor and encouragement here, but I think they realized that there was something to be done here.
Now, the people who are sort of particularly important and

encouraging and supporting the growth of the Oceanographic Program were not so much within the office itself, but in the Office of the Chief of Naval Operations, people concerned with anti-submarine warfare and pro-submarine warfare and so on, the operating forces.
And it was largely through their
interest that we got the support and opportunities we did.
What about ONR?
Well, ONR, I have to stop and think here again.
That got started when, about 46?
It's not really called ONR then, but Revell begins to think about ONR in 46.
Yes, it was the Office of, what was it called, something rather off, or
Something and Invention.
Yeah, right.
It's a strange title.
Yes, and it must have got established about that time, and Revelle then moved from the Bureau of Ships to the newly established

And, of course, the establishment of ONR was, in a sense, a response to the phasing out of these wartime research activities under NDRC and the parent organization, which was OSRD, Office of Scientific Research and Development, I guess it was.
So the Navy was, in a sense, trying to find some mechanism to keep some of their programs going.
We worked very sort of closely together, although I cannot remember that there were ever any sort of transfer of funds or anything as one might anticipate in more recent times.
But I actually spent almost a year of it, and it must have been about 1949-50, I spent the better part of a year actually in ONR on loan, in a sense, from the
Hydrographic Office to work on planning and so forth as related to anti-submarine problems.
And so there was a good sort of, I think, there was no conflict there as I ran into some sort of
difficulties that you'd almost anticipate anywhere, but I had really very good rapport, I think, with the people in the Hydrographic Office, and CNO, and ONR, and Bureau of Ships, and so on.
So, no, I don't feel there was any
antagonism, certainly there was a difference in perspectives on a lot of the problems.

I went back to Washington with the idea that we ought to be doing a lot of work on the Arctic, and this had seemed to me a good sort of subject in which we knew very little and that we ought to be doing some work up there and

And here's where we got into lack of appreciation on the part of the particularly CNO who informed me and my boss, the hydrographer, in no uncertain terms that the Navy had no plans to operate in the Arctic and therefore had no
reason to want to spend any money trying to find out about it.
So one of the things I was able to do, in part with assistance from ONR and some others, was to in effect bootleg some, get some work started in the Arctic.
